newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria has $59 mln cap account surplus Jan-Sept.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria has $59 mln cap account surplus Jan-Sept.

text.p: Bulgaria posted a capital account suplus of $58.6 million for the first nine month of this year after a $325.2 million deficit for the same period of 1995, Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) preliminary figures showed.

Portfolio investments' net change for the first nine months was $183.8 million as liabilities to foreign lenders decreased by $116.7 million, mainly due to maturity payments on Bulbank's Eurobonds, and the country's assets abroad rose by $67.1 million, the BNB said in a statement.
Bulgaria received $259.1 million payments on long-term loans to other countries in the first nine months, figures showed.
Commercial banks' deposits abroad fell by $90.7 million from January through September against a $63.3 million fall for the same period of 1995.

Resident capital outflow continued in the third quarter due to low confidence in Bulgaria's shaky banking system, the BNB said. Private companies and individuals have withdrawn some $622 million from local banks during the first nine months, figures showed. @
Principal payments on long-term and short-term loans from foreigh lenders totalled $301.4 million in the first nine months, up $62.9 million year-on-year.
BNB foreign exchange reserves fell by $763.9 million from January through September to $506.3 million, BNB figures showed. -- Anastas Petrov, Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-876032
